Award.AwardTitle: Non-Heme Iron(II)-Nitroxyl Complexes: Modeling Key Intermediates in Nitric Oxide Reductases
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Nicolai Lehnert from the University of Michigan to study how the molecule nitric oxide is broken down by bacteria. Nitric oxide (NO) is a simple but very important molecule in human physiology as it is involved in the control of blood pressure and serves as a key immune defense agent. However, some bacteria have evolved defenses against this molecule by using certain enzymes which destroy it. This project is working toward understanding the fundamental mechanism by which these enzymes are able to break down NO. The fundamental understanding of the chemistry that these bacterial enzymes catalyze is contributing to the effort to find new cures against drug resistant bacterial infections. In addition, this project is training graduate and undergraduate students in chemical synthesis, analytical characterization techniques, advanced spectroscopic methods, and how to approach and solve scientific problem). These are all valuable skills for students when they enter the job market. Finally, outreach with Cass Technical High School in Detroit is integrated in to this project by allowing underrepresented minority high school students to work in the Lehnert laboratory over the summer and obtain research experience.

This research project is aimed at using model complexes for the active site of flavodiiron nitric oxide reductases (FNORs) to map out potential chemical pathways of how NO reduction can be accomplished by non-heme diiron sites. In previous work, the Lehnert group prepared the first functional model complex, which forms the basis for the current mechanistic studies. Using spectroscopic and kinetic studies, coupled to DFT calculations, the researchers determine the molecular mechanism by which this complex catalyzes the NOR reaction. By preparing suitable derivatives of this species, they define the geometric and electronic requirements for efficient NO reduction and N2O generation by non-heme diiron active sites in general, and further explore different mechanistic possibilities. These studies ultimately identify chemically feasible pathways for NO reduction in FNORs and provide fingerprints of important intermediates of this reaction. The research group performs detailed reactivity studies on this model system in order to gain a better understanding of how non-heme (high-spin) iron(II)-nitroxyl complexes could be involved in NOR catalysis and, potentially, HNO biosynthesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Important contributions of this project to society relate to the importance of the gas nitric oxide (NO) in medicine. NO is biosynthesized in the human body and serves both as a neurotransmitter and a signaling molecule involved in blood pressure control, but also as a very potent immune defense agent. The human immune system employs a number of strategies to combat pathogenic infection, one of them being the release of NO (for example, by macrophages), which is very efficient in killing invading organisms. However, a number of pathogens have developed the ability to detoxify NO by reduction to N2O, using enzymes called flavodiiron nitric oxide reductases (FNORs) to accomplish this task. These enzymes therefore promote pathogenic infection of the human body, leading to acute and chronic infections and inflammations that are more difficult to cure. The work conducted in my group provides insight into the mechanism of these important enzymes by using chemical model systems that allow us to study different mechanistic alternatives for these enzymes, obtain chemical insight into the different steps of the reaction, and identify important intermediates of the process. For this purpose, we have designed diiron complexes that model the active site of FNORs. While decades of research have focused on the interaction of NO with hemoglobin/myoglobin and other heme-containing proteins, much less is known about the binding and redox transformations of nitric oxide with iron centers that are not bound to heme, and that are therefore termed “non-heme” iron. This project has already elucidated key elements of the mechanism of FNORs. In particular, our work has shown that reduced non-heme iron(II)-NO- complexes are likely key intermediates of the process. Using specially designed chemical model systems, we have determined the properties of these types of complexes, and we have studied different reactions that these species can mediate. Other than NO reduction to N2O, non-heme iron(II)-NO- complexes are also involved in the generation of dinitrosyl iron complexes (DNICs = Fe(NO)2 type species), where a non-heme iron center is bound to two NO ligands (see below). By investigating the catalytic mechanism of FNORs, our work makes important contributions to the greater effort of finding new cures against bacterial infections, in particular drug-resistant strains.

 

The NO produced in the human body can be stored in several ways, most prominently by the formation of either nitrosothiols or DNICs. Here, DNICs result from the reaction of NO with the labile iron pool in the human body, but the mechanism of this process is not well understood. DNICs have many important functions in humans in NO storage, sensing, and NO transfer to other reactive species (thiols, hemes). We have obtained insight into the bimolecular mechanism by which mononuclear non-heme iron(II)-NO- complexes form DNICs. We have trapped a dimeric Fe2(NO)2 intermediate that represents the key step that generates the Fe(NO)2 unit of DNICs. Our work therefore provides general insight into the potential roles that non-heme iron-NO adducts play in Biology and human physiology.

 

Besides these scientific aspects, the outreach program with Cass Technical High School in Detroit that I started in Summer 2014 (UM Detroit Research Internship Summer Experience, D-RISE) has made important contributions to increase underrepresented minority representation in the sciences by motivating the participating students to attend college and to work in STEM areas. D-RISE provides 7 weeks full-time summer internships to high school students from Cass Tech and Wolverine Pathways (WP; a supplemental educational program by the University of Michigan) in the UM Chemistry Department. The most important hallmark of this program is that the high school students do not just observe their graduate student and/or post­doctoral mentors in the laboratory, but the high school students perform full-time hands-on research for 40 hours per week on projects that are directly related to their mentors’ work. In this way, the participating high school students obtain a real research experience, and they are in fact able to produce enough results from their own work to fill full-size research posters at the end of the project. These posters are usually presented by the high school students at the Department of Chemistry Graduate Students Research Symposium (the Karle Symposium). It is clear that D-RISE is having a strong and positive impact on the student participants. Of the 22 students who participated in D-RISE in Summer 2014­–2018, all but one applied to UM for admission to the undergraduate program; 16 were admitted, and 13 of the students are now pursuing undergraduate studies at UM (81%). Notably, many of the D-RISE students who are attending UM have entered STEM areas (chemistry, biochemistry, neuroscience, environmental science and engineering). The students all commented on the strong impact of this experience, further motivating them to pursue STEM careers. Working with high school students provides further, valuable mentoring opportunities to the participating graduate students.
